items.title: Happy 2026! Will this be the year we finally achieve AGI? I‚Äôd like to propose a new version of the T...
items.content:
Happy 2026! Will this be the year we finally achieve AGI? I‚Äôd like to propose a new version of the Turing Test, which I‚Äôll call the Turing-AGI Test, to see if we‚Äôve achieved this. I‚Äôll explain in a moment why having a new test is important.

The public thinks achieving AGI means computers will be as intelligent as people and be able to do most or all knowledge work. I‚Äôd like to propose a new test. The test subject ‚Äî either a computer or a skilled professional human ‚Äî is given access to a computer that has internet access and software such as a web browser and Zoom. The judge will design a multi-day experience for the test subject, mediated through the computer, to carry out work tasks. For example, an experience might consist of a period of training (say, as a call center operator), followed by being asked to carry out the task (taking calls), with ongoing feedback. This mirrors what a remote worker with a fully working computer (but no webcam) might be expected to do.

A computer passes the Turing-AGI Test if it can carry out the work task as well as a skilled human.

Most members of the public likely believe a real AGI system will pass this test. Surely, if computers are as intelligent as humans, they should be able to perform work tasks as well as a human one might hire. Thus, the Turing-AGI Test aligns with the popular notion of what AGI means.

Here‚Äôs why we need a new test: ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù has turned into a term of hype rather than a term with a precise meaning. A reasonable definition of AGI is AI that can do any intellectual task that a human can. When businesses hype up that they might achieve AGI within a few quarters, they usually try to justify these statements by setting a much lower bar. This mismatch in definitions is harmful because it makes people think AI is becoming more powerful than it actually is. I‚Äôm seeing this mislead everyone from high-school students (who avoid certain fields of study because they think it‚Äôs pointless with AGI‚Äôs imminent arrival) to CEOs (who are deciding what projects to invest in, sometimes assuming AI will be more capable in 1-2 years than any likely reality).

The original Turing Test, which required a computer to fool a human judge, via text chat, into being unable to distinguish it from a human, has been insufficient to indicate human-level intelligence. The Loebner Prize competition actually ran the Turing Test and found that being able to simulate human typing errors ‚Äî perhaps even more than actually demonstrating intelligence ‚Äî was needed to fool judges. A main goal of AI development today is to build systems that can do economically useful work, not fool judges. Thus a modified test that measures ability to do work would be more useful than a test that measures the ability to fool humans.

For almost all AI benchmarks today (such as GPQA, AIME, SWE-bench, etc.), a test set is determined in advance. This means AI teams end up at least indirectly tuning their models to the published test sets. Further, any fixed test set measures only one narrow sliver of intelligence. In contrast, in the Turing Test, judges are free to ask any question to probe the model as they please. This lets a judge test how ‚Äúgeneral‚Äù the knowledge of the computer or human really is. Similarly, in the Turing-AGI Test, the judge can design any experience ‚Äî which is not revealed in advance to the AI (or human subject) being tested. This is a better way to measure generality of AI than a predetermined test set.

AI is on an amazing trajectory of progress. In previous decades, overhyped expectations led to AI winters, when disappointment about AI capabilities caused reductions in interest and funding, which picked up again when the field made more progress. One of the few things that could get in the way of AI‚Äôs tremendous momentum is unrealistic hype that creates an investment bubble, risking disappointment and a collapse of interest. To avoid this, we need to recalibrate society‚Äôs expectations on AI. A test will help.

If we run a Turing-AGI Test competition and every AI system falls short, that will be a good thing! By defusing hype around AGI and reducing the chance of a bubble, we will create a more reliable path to continued investment in AI. This will let us keep on driving forward real technological progress and building valuable applications ‚Äî even ones that fall well short of AGI. And if this test sets a clear target that teams can aim toward to claim the mantle of achieving AGI, that would be wonderful, too. And we can be confident that if a company passes this test, they will have created more than just a marketing release ‚Äî it will be something incredibly valuable.

[Original text: https://t.co/mGAmoOGga7 ]

items.title: @matrix_opt @giffmana Dude, your stupid and utterly ignorant attacks don't deserve that anyone spend...
items.content:
@matrix_opt @giffmana Dude, your stupid and utterly ignorant attacks don't deserve that anyone spend any time responding to them.
How much do enjoy doing character assassination while cowardly hiding your identity behind a random handle?
Own your opinions.
You have absolutely no idea of what you are talking about here.

Shared weights were in the original backprop paper in the PDP book (look up to T-C problem).
TDNN (or 1D CNN) were actually invented and published by Geoff Hinton and Kevin Lang at CMU.
They published a tech report (not a journal paper) because they weren't beating the best CMU ASR system with it.
Then, Alex Waibel (who knew nothing about neural nets at the time) ***TOOK THE CODE*** from Kevin, went to ATR in Japan, got some better results than the ATR system (which wasn't as good as the CMU system) and wrote a journal paper.
Geoff and Kevin were pissed as hell (I was a postdoc with Geoff when this whole thing happened).
My ConvNet papers cite Kevin's tech report, not Alex's. Alex was actually mad at me for this.

The original TDNNs from Kevin had only one convolutional layer.
The first *real* (multilayer) TDNNs with pooling/subsampling for speech recognition were done by L√©on Bottou. He could recognize whole words with it (the original TDNN could only do phonemes). Yoshua Bengio also had results on this a bit later.
I hired both of them at Bell Labs because they also worked on sentence-level training with backprop through a time alignment. We used similar ideas for our check reader.
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: Yann LeCun provides detailed historical correction about deep learning origins: shared weights were in original backprop paper, TDNNs invented by Hinton/Lang (not Waibel), and clarifies L√©on Bottou's contributions to multilayer TDNNs with pooling.
items.reasoning: Invaluable first-hand historical account from AI pioneer correcting the record on foundational deep learning innovations. Massive engagement (326k views), primary source documentation of ML history.

items.title: In 2024, I was delighted to be a co-author on an Arxiv paper on"Shaping AI's Impact on Billions of L...
items.content:
In 2024, I was delighted to be a co-author on an Arxiv paper on"Shaping AI's Impact on Billions of Lives", covering areas we thought AI would have significant impact on the world.  We cover AI's potential impact on employment, education, healthcare, (mis)information, media, national security, and science, and propose 18 potential moonshot research directions in these areas to maximize positive impact and minimize downsides. A shortened version appears as the cover article in this month's Communications of the ACM (CACM).

CACM version: https://t.co/996f1lfA9r (~12 pages + video discussion with David Patterson)

Arxiv: https://t.co/sBRkdIGo2x (expanded 30 page version)

You can find these and more at: https://t.co/pwDUiMRJZ5

It was a delight to work on this with awesome co-authors!  Authors: Mariano-Florentino Cu√©llar, myself (@JeffDean), @FinaleDoshi, John Hennessy, @andykonwinski, @sanmikoyejo, @tamati_biskit, @2plus2make5, and David Patterson.

(PDF link of CACM version is a bit hard to find.  It's at https://t.co/hC5sri3Enq)

items.reasoning: Major policy-relevant publication from Google's Chief Scientist with co-authors including Hennessy and Patterson. Comprehensive scope, actionable research agenda, high credibility.

items.title: For our free newsletter this week, we cover AI for strategic forgetting: systems that decide what or...
items.content:
For our free newsletter this week, we cover AI for strategic forgetting: systems that decide what organizations should unknow.


@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week.
¬†
AI for strategic forgetting is software that looks through an organization‚Äôs data, documents, and models to find information that is old, biased, risky, or no longer needed, then suggests or performs deletion or safe archiving. 

It treats stored data as something that can cause harm as well as help, so it uses clear rules, human oversight, and audit trails to clean up the past without secretly erasing important evidence or history.

Read and subscribe for free: https://t.co/HHwYy7NoAl

Back to CES, seeing a ton of stuff today. Starting with @LumusVision wave guides (they make the displays for the Meta Rayban AI glasses with displays).

items.summary: Scobleizer introduces concept of 'AI for strategic forgetting' - systems that identify outdated, biased, or risky organizational data for deletion/archiving with human oversight and audit trails
items.reasoning: Novel AI concept addressing data governance and liability. Credible tech journalist with 27K views. Original framework for thinking about data lifecycle in AI systems.

CES 2026. Robots from Shenzhen.

This defines a lot about CES this year. There is a ton of these humanoid robots from various Chinese companies; they do cool movement, fighting, and dancing, but they are not generalized and not very useful yet. I haven't really seen a robot that I would actually want in my home.

LG's CLOi is the closest, but that's also a fairly early robot that they're planning on selling in a year or two. Still, this defines CES for me this year, as we didn't see this quantity of humanoid robots last year.

Makes low power AI chips inside a wide range of consumer products. Watches, rings, AI glasses, medical devices, all use their chips because they are best at running neural networks at very low power.

This gives you a lot of insights into the future.

items.title: @adam_x_mentis I disagree. Humanoids will bring specific-task robots to your house because they'll b...
items.content:
@adam_x_mentis I disagree. Humanoids will bring specific-task robots to your house because they'll be generalized. They can fit into any situation, and specialized robots can't do that.

A mimetic robot is never going to get up and wash the dishes. Why would I have a specialized robot doing every freaking task of my life? It takes too much space in my house. Having one robot do a lot of tasks makes a lot more sense.

Consider these points:
1. In a factory floor, you have to crawl underneath the dash (something a specialized machine might struggle with).
2. Elon already tried specialized robots, and they didn't work.

You need to build something that is like a human being‚Äîsomething that can manipulate the world like a human being.

items.summary: Detailed argument for humanoid robots over specialized ones: generalization, space efficiency, human-like manipulation needed for complex tasks like reaching under car dashes
items.reasoning: Substantive robotics design philosophy from credible commentator. References Elon's failed specialized robot attempts. Clear reasoning for humanoid approach.

items.title: The new software development paradigm: the purity of the codebase is no longer the holy cow protecte...
items.content:
The new software development paradigm: the purity of the codebase is no longer the holy cow protected by angry senior devs.

Companies will use agentic code systems like Claude Code Opus 4.5 to fix messy codebases as long as they are fixable.

Once each new fix starts taking too much time or consuming too many tokens, the entire non-fixable piece will be rewritten from scratch based on the spec and the unit tests remaining from the previous non-fixable version.

No human will be involved in the code writing. Only in the spec and test writing.

items.summary: Burkov predicts new software paradigm: agentic systems like Claude Code Opus 4.5 will fix messy codebases until unfixable, then rewrite from scratch. Humans only write specs and tests, not code.

items.title: One of the most important papers of 2025 solves the problem of diffusion language models not being a...
items.content:
One of the most important papers of 2025 solves the problem of diffusion language models not being able to generate outputs of arbitrary lengths and not being SOTA in language modeling.

LMs today mostly generate text one word at a time from left to right, which is slow but produces high-quality output. An alternative approach called diffusion‚Äîwhere you start with random noise and gradually refine it into coherent text‚Äîcan generate multiple words in parallel but historically produces worse results and can only output fixed-length sequences.

This paper figures out how to get the benefits of both by splitting text into chunks and using diffusion within each chunk while generating chunks sequentially. The authors discover that a major reason diffusion models underperform is not the math itself but the high variance in gradient estimates during training, which makes learning unstable.

They then design noise schedules that reduce this variance, which turns out to be the key to closing the quality gap. The result is a model that matches diffusion's parallelism, supports generating documents of any length (previous diffusion models could not do this), enables efficiency tricks previously available only to standard models, and achieves the best perplexity scores among diffusion approaches.

Read online and ask questions on the way: https://t.co/tBDV2vghjK

Download the PDF: https://t.co/FC8QbrbqKO

See the full curriculum of the most important 2025 papers: https://t.co/ZmXqGkNvOn

The curriculum is continuously updated with new items as new citations are discovered.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov summarizes key 2025 paper on diffusion language models that solves arbitrary-length generation by chunking text and reducing gradient variance during training.
items.reasoning: Educational summary of important technical paper on diffusion LMs. Addresses key limitation of diffusion approaches, provides accessible explanation.

items.title:
It's crazy how easy it is to spot many AI-generated replies.

Obviously, there's selection bias here...
items.content:
It's crazy how easy it is to spot many AI-generated replies.

Obviously, there's selection bias here, but every day, I get between 5 and 10 replies that are clearly AI-generated.

A common pattern to spot AI slop is to look for contrastive parallelism:

[X is not the goal. Y is]

For example: 

‚Ä¢ Compute isn't an advantage. Better evaluation is.
‚Ä¢ Features aren't the product. Outcomes are.

Any time you see this, there's a high chance the text came directly from an AI model.

Block these people. There's no other way to deal with this.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Pino shares guide on spotting AI-generated replies, identifying 'contrastive parallelism' pattern (e.g., 'X isn't the goal. Y is') as a tell, recommends blocking such accounts
items.reasoning: Practical guide for detecting AI-generated content. Addresses growing concern about AI slop on social platforms.

AI first starts with a mindset shift that most leaders miss.

Old software was deterministic. If X then Y.

AI is probabilistic and pattern unlocking.

This requires leaders to:

‚Üí Reimagine every process, not digitize the old one.

This is a fundamentally different operating model.

items.title: @matrix_opt @giffmana "Transducer" is the technique proposed by Fernando Pereira and Mike Riley for ...
items.content:
@matrix_opt @giffmana "Transducer" is the technique proposed by Fernando Pereira and Mike Riley for FSM-based language models in NLP and speech recognition (they were our colleagues at Bell Labs).
We used this concept, made it differentiable, called the resulting deep architecture Graph Transformer Networks (GTN), and used it for end-to-end training of character recognition at the sequence level.
First paper on this published at ICASSP 1997:
https://t.co/vJGtkQFiUO
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: YLeCun explains historical context of 'Transducer' concept from Pereira and Riley at Bell Labs, and how it led to Graph Transformer Networks (GTN) for end-to-end character recognition training.
items.reasoning: Historical technical context from AI pioneer. Documents evolution of key concepts in sequence modeling and neural networks.

items.title:
@isaac_flath Yeah concrete examples 

1. ‚ÄúLook how many lines of code I've created.‚Äù This can be tra...
items.content:
@isaac_flath Yeah concrete examples 

1. ‚ÄúLook how many lines of code I've created.‚Äù This can be translated to: "Hello, look at all the technical debt that I've created." 

2. ‚ÄúI refactored this codebase to have 80% less code." -  truly deleting lines of code such that you don't repeat yourself or using a community-wide trusted dependency is really good. However quite often this is the result of an idiosyncratic/personal dependency and are cleverly hiding the code behind that, or unecessary code golf.

So either way it is not the best metric
items.author: @HamelHusain
items.summary: Critiques lines of code as metric - more code often means technical debt, and refactoring to less code can hide complexity in dependencies
items.reasoning: Thoughtful take on AI coding metrics relevant to vibe coding discourse. Practical wisdom for AI-assisted development.

And the software stack itself is about to face a reckoning.

20th century architectures cannot keep up with agentic AI.

They require heart surgery every time a policy, org structure, or product changes.

Winning companies will adopt platforms that separate:

‚Üí Data
‚Üí Business logic
‚Üí Workflows

This creates systems that evolve continuously instead of breaking every quarter.

The vendor relationship shifts from procurement to true partnership.

items.title:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People ...
items.content:
The biggest blocker to adoption is not technology. It is fear.

Hala Zeine said it clearly.

People love the idea of change. They just prefer it to happen to someone else.

What works:

‚Üí Leaders who communicate the vision repeatedly.
‚Üí Small teams that are willing to experiment and showcase visible wins.
‚Üí A culture where leaders admit what they know, what they do not know, and what they will figure out together.

AI transformation is a leadership challenge before it becomes a technical one.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Identifies fear as biggest AI adoption blocker, recommends visible wins, experimental teams, and transparent leadership
items.reasoning: Practical organizational change management insights for AI adoption. Cites specific interview source.

Some of those advantages:
1) Skills can be more easily be centralized & managed than GPTs

items.title:
If my salary is $10,000/month, I would save $3,000 and invest $1,000 first thing.

Then everything e...
items.content:
If my salary is $10,000/month, I would save $3,000 and invest $1,000 first thing.

Then everything else is budgeted around the remaining.

I would definitely not spend $2,600/month on traveling, probably much less, like every 3 months or something.

I would spend time working on my side projects instead (for a better future).

When I save up to ~2-3 years of living costs, I would quit the job and attempt to build my own business from the side projects I have created.

If I fail, I find a job, save up, and try again.

There is no way I‚Äôll accept working 9-5 for the rest of my life. The sooner I escape the better.

items.content:
CRM applications were not built for the world we live in.

They are passive databases. They are outdated and a waste of time.

Lightfield is completely different.

This is a CRM that automatically builds itself from your email, calendar, and meetings.

‚Ä¢ Zero manual entry
‚Ä¢ Natural language as the primary interface
‚Ä¢ AI agents that proactively manage workflows for you

Lightfield is proactive. It's all about "understanding" your business.

It knows when to reach out, what context matters, and which relationships need attention.

You can see why at https://t.co/Yx2WNOMrtq.

Thanks to the team for collaborating with me on this post.

items.content:
How operators monetize Flow

I walk through a simple playbook:

1. Identify the ‚Äúcan‚Äôt-fail‚Äù journeys in your market
2. Map deterministic performance targets (latency, jitter, loss)
3. Productize SLAs as add-ons with clear uptime and credits

Result ‚Üí differentiated connectivity becomes a business model, not a best-effort commodity.

items.summary: Outlines playbook for operators to monetize deterministic network performance through SLA productization

items.title: @s_artur50416 Not with every change, but only when the code is so messy that it cannot be fixed chea...
items.content:
@s_artur50416 Not with every change, but only when the code is so messy that it cannot be fixed cheaply enough. Then it will be recreated from scratch, which corresponds to the notion of a version increase in traditional software development.

Passing from version 1 to version 2 often comes with a different UI, and the users are used to it.
